review.title: A hybrid spatial data mining approach based on fuzzy topological relations and MOSES evolutionary algorithm
review.abstract: Making high-quality decisions in strategic spatial planning is heavily dependent on extracting knowledge from vast amounts of data. Although many decision-making problems like developing urban areas require such perception and reasoning, existing methods in this field usually neglect the deep knowledge mined from geographic databases and are based on pure statistical methods. Due to the large volume of data gathered in spatial databases, and the uncertainty of spatial objects, mining association rules for high-level knowledge representation is a challenging task. Few algorithms manage geographical and non-geographical data using topological relations. In this paper, a novel approach for spatial data mining based on the MOSES evolutionary framework is presented which improves the classic genetic programming approach. A hybrid architecture called GGeo is proposed to apply the MOSES mining rules considering fuzzy topological relations from spatial data. The uncertainty and fuzziness aspects are addressed using an enriched model of topological relations by fuzzy region connection calculus. Moreover, to overcome the problem of time-consuming fuzzy topological relationships calculations, this a novel data pre-processing method is offered. GGeo analyses and learns from geographical and non-geographical data and uses topological and distance parameters, and returns a series of arithmetic-spatial formulas as classification rules. The proposed approach is resistant to noisy data, and all its stages run in parallel to increase speed. This approach may be used in different spatial data classification problems as well as representing an appropriate method of data analysis and economic policy making.

metadata.title: A hybrid spatial data mining approach based on fuzzy topological relations and MOSES evolutionary algorithm

sections.text: Although many decision-making issues, such as urban development, require such perception and reasoning, existing methods in this area generally neglect the deep knowledge gained from geographical databases and are based on purely statistical methods. Due to the large volume of data collected in spatial databases and the uncertainty of spatial objects, the Mining Association's rules for the representation of high-level knowledge are challenging. Few algorithms manage geographical and non-geographical data using topological relationships. This paper presents a novel approach to spatial data mining based on the evolutionary framework of MOSES and improves the classical genetic programming approach. A hybrid architecture called GGeo proposes to apply the MOSES mining rules taking into account unclear topological relationships from spatial data.

sections.heading: 3. The proposed method
sections.text: In this section, the proposed GGeo-T and GGeo-P architectures are presented after an overview of some important underlying concepts.

sections.heading: 3.1. Evolutionary algorithms
sections.text: Evolutionary algorithms (EA) use stochastic search results as inspiration for the natural evolutionary process. EA methods often share the following rules: 1-EAs work with a population of individuals (candidate solutions) rather than with a single candidate solution; 2-EAs use a biased evaluation function to obtain some of the genetic material; 3-EAs create new individuals who are usually able to identify with another.

sections.heading: 3.2. The MOSES automated program learning
sections.text: MOSES performs a supervised learning and uses a scoring function or training data as input. MOSES sends a "combo program" to the output that estimates the scoring function. MOSES creates a population of programs and then searches for neighbors and "mutated" programs and calculates their fitness. After a certain number of iterations, the best program is presented as a result. MOSES in particular constructs a population of "Demes." Each Demme is a program with many tunable parameters. These parameters are called "buttons." So it is not just a matter of finding the best demme, but also of selecting the best demme with the best controller settings. MOSES selects a demme and performs random mutations on it. This is done by inserting new controllers in random places. The best controller settings for each program are disabled.

sections.heading: 3.3. The need for preprocessing along with MOSES
sections.text: As described in Section 3.1, determining the functional set is crucial for GP. The functional set has a high impact on the population number and length of the trees. If GP is used to classify many datasets with many attributes, it results in a large population and long individual length, which results in a high computational load. On the other hand, the geographic functions for expressing the topological and geometric relationships between spatial data require a lot more calculations. A solution to these problems can be achieved by an architecture that pre-processes geographical relationships with the least impact on meaningfulness, which will greatly affect the time and storage requirements. Considering the geographical relationships calculated in the pre-processing phase, this requires more calculations.

sections.heading: 3.4. Spatial relationships
sections.text: Topological relationships are a certain class of spatial relations defined between two spatial or geographical relations (CC Method 1992). Other classes of spatial relations are distance relations that determine the order of objects. A distance relationship is a positive real number and can also be expressed with less precision using phrases such as "close to" and "far from." Political relations represent the relative position of an object to another and require the handling of space. Thus, a reference system and an axis are necessary (e.g. for the three-dimensional argumentation of a system with relations "right of," "above," "below," before, "behind," geographical. "Boolean topological relations between two objects are based on the concepts of intersection, internality and externality. A well-known formalism for topological relations is RCC, in which all relations between entities are derived from a connecting predicate.

sections.heading: 3.5. The proposed architecture – GGeo
sections.text: In this section, the GGeo architecture is presented as a novel hybrid data mining approach that uses a combination of spatial data pre-processing and automated MOSES learning algorithm. It efficiently performs classification tasks in geographical databases. GGeo unifies geographical constraints and operation at each instance. Two related architectures are proposed, as can be seen in Figure 3, which are described as follows.3.5.1. Inputs and outputs of GGeo The inputs to the system are a collection of numerical, Boolean, spatial characteristics. In classifying cities, for example, the numerical characteristics are population, Gini index, and the Boolean characteristics are provincial capitals and geographical characteristics such as city maps, streets and rivers, which are in line and polygon form. GGeo creates a different program for each class, learning from the training data (for example, some cities) and then classifying test spatial characteristics accordingly.

sections.heading: TF = Target Feature
sections.text: In fact, it is not that it is a mere thought game, but an attempt to change the world, "he told" Welt am Sonntag ":" I don't think we will be able to change the world. sections.heading: 4. Experimental evaluation
sections.text: In this section, the proposed GGeo architecture is applied to real-world data, and the results are presented as evidence of its efficiency.

sections.heading: 4.1. Raw dataset
sections.text: The spatial datasets used in this study are converted into the WGS84 system. Geographical points are represented with latitude and longitude, each of which is represented with double precision using decimals. Iranian cities are geographical polygons, which are sets of points with the same start and end point. In each city, general attributes such as population and the latest update are shown, the date is also provided. Iranian roads were extracted from OpenStreetMap-OSM in the form of geographical lines (sets of ordered points). Other Iranian data came from the MapCrusine website. After data collection, the geometric data was extracted in WKT format. The entire map circumference was taken with vertical and horizontal grid lines to calculate the spatial relationships of the features.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and future work
sections.text: In this paper, GGeo was proposed as a novel hybrid data mining approach to classify spatial characteristics such as cities in geographical databases where spatial and non-spatial data are present. Iranian cities were used as case studies to illustrate the approach. Comprehensive evaluation showed that the use of fuzzy topology relationships can significantly increase the quality of knowledge in geographical databases. Furthermore, the GGeo architecture, which benefits from the evolutionary MOSES algorithm, is competitive and robust, and has excellent noise tolerance. A pre-processing approach proposed as a plugin for geoquette further improved the algorithm. Future work may include the use of association rules extracted into strategic decisions to improve Gatim quality.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We would like to thank the members of the OpenCog project who helped us develop the original idea and the introduction of MOSES. We would also like to thank Marconi de Arruda Pereira for the datasets and source code of DMGeo.

referenceMentions.context: In relational databases, every feature type is usually stored in a different table or relation (Shekhar and Chawla, 2003).
This approach exploited the Spada algorithm (Lisi and Malerba, 2002).
have also used an extended similar approach (Sitanggang et al., 2011).
Their GeoDMA method creates a set of descriptive features that improve the classification accuracy (Körting et al., 2013).
In this area, Genetic Programming (GP) is exploited as a method to automatically generate computer programs using a process similar to biological evolution (Koza, 1992).
Spatial relationships are not explicitly stored in a database, and they should be calculated with spatial operations (Bogorny et al., 2005).

This is done regardless of any prior knowledge and provides automation in two granular level for the resulting file namely feature type granularity level and feature instance granularity level (Bogorny et al., 2005).

(de Arruda Pereira et al., 2010) which 290 are of class A and 290 are of B. Iran cities data set is generated by the authors under the supervision of urban planning experts and contains spatial and non-spatial data of 268 Iranian cities like their population, the number of hotels and educational index. 53 of them are labeled High (A), 128 of them are labeled Medium (B) and 87 of them are labeled Low(C). The performance of the proposed method GGeo is analysed by applying it in 6 classification problems. Two datasets(Heart and Wine databases) containing non-spatial data are available in the UCI Machine Learning Repository(2014b) and are used only to evaluate MOSES.
